personally, I am a bit split on the idea of project-level linting... not sure how necessary it is for this project, but in this case I'm trying to fix the problem without a long discussion about how useful the linter is.

no, the rendered html gets validated by the browser devtools
ah, I see, I see what you mean
taking this one step at a time, do you have any concerns against using another validator?
the one we chose is the only one that we needed to satisfy to get an error-free console for the JS repl
well, yes, but other validators should work too, I suppose
in this case, I think factoring in Java to an already complicated project is quite unnecessary
so yeah, let's switch to the other validator, make sure we don't get any warnings and in the meantime discuss if a project-wide html validator is even necessary/
prolly smart to leave it to a CI job for the time being
the Java validator you mean?

just that we should not use that one

a few things here

content.body: The problem here is that it does not clearly communicate why the tool needs to be introduced in a way that runs counter to the problem we are trying to solve. A clear comparison table will persuade many members if that makes sense.
https://github.com/zrrrzzt/html-validator#html-validator the first line here would imply that the two tools are replaceable
what I'm trying to say is that nobody else's opinion on what is "valid" html matters except for the official w3c validator
I disagree here
the w3c publishes an "official" validator, but any implementation should work
well if the goal is to get a nice clean JS REPL
again, (1) I disagree that this justifies bringing in Java code (2) we can get a clean REPL with any other validator too
if an alternative validator fails this, then it's a bug in that implementation
no, because even warnings issued by that validator will show up

This is very to the point. We are not aiming to get rid of errors completely (Even if it's great). It would be great if we could use a validator to improve things like accessibility -- valid HTML is useful to many people, but the goal here is not a zero-error.

reading https://github.com/tc39/tc39.github.io/issues/264 I don't know what order things are being tackled here, but if there's investigation into the main framework it may be worth putting any changes on the back burner until that's decided. there's no point putting effort into packaging up a validator if we move to something that doesn't generate invalid html in the first place

content.body: A few things here
I decided to start with this because after discussing with Yulia, I realized that we could simplify the project without having to move away from Jekyll or doing a rewrite.
ugh did I accidentally ping you?
Jekyll works as expected, it's all the additional cruft like the validator that's making the project so complicated
I strongly disagree with the whole idea that we need that particular validator in order to check our HTML.
whether we need a validator at all or not is a separate question I think I feel less strongly about.
but only relatively so. Even the general idea of a validator seems rather overkill to me tbh.
if Jekyll builds it and it renders then I think it's good enough for us. Having no console warnings is great but not a strict requirement for this website to do its job well.
by the way, `html-validate` has granular options for lint rules and has a present that matches our current tool
content.formatted_body: by the way, html-validate has granular options for lint rules and has a present that matches our current tool

content.body: https://html-validate.org/rules/presets.html#html-validate-standard
if we use this preset, it should have the exact same behavior than the Java tool
* if we use this preset, it should have the exact same behavior than the Java tool

m.new_content.body: if we use this preset, it should have the exact same behavior than the Java tool

content.body: if the Java tool worked with no warnings, then even that preset is stricter, we'll try to match exactly the level of strictness.

@ryzokuken worth noting if it’s not an `npm i` and you need the gemfiles you will also need to keep the Dockerfile and container setup. It’s also worth putting some opinions on the issues I opened too

content.body: sure, I'll visit them first thing tomorrow.

Docker was added in the first place because there were originally issues setting up ruby + Gem and not everyone had it installed, so the ruby image was added. Keeping Jekyll would mean keeping that also, otherwise you’ll end up making the friction more. It less.
